item.title: 吃1种水果，保护自己免受“沉默杀手”和痴呆症的侵害- Surrey Live | Protect yourself from 'silent killer' and dementia by eating 1 fruit - Surrey Live
item.description:
With heart disease being a top cause of death globally, experts suggest that one particular fruit might be one of the best weapons against it. Research claims that eating a handful every day might naturally help support heart health and manage cholesterol.

The bright and sweet summer superfood - the strawberry - is one of the most popular fruits eaten by millions of people worldwide. These berries are available at all major UK supermarkets, or you could easily grow your own personal supply at home.

Researchers from the University of California, Davis, reviewed dozens of clinical trials and observational studies from 2000 to 2023. They found that strawberries contain phytonutrients like polyphenols and fibre, which help reduce LDL 'bad' cholesterol, triglycerides, and inflammation, promoting heart health.

High cholesterol, especially elevated levels of LDL cholesterol, is often referred to as a 'silent killer'. This is because typically, there are no obvious symptoms until it results in severe health issues like a heart attack or stroke. Since it often goes unnoticed without testing, it can accumulate in the arteries over time, potentially leading to serious complications.

As strawberries ripen, they develop more of these phytonutrients, specifically anthocyanins, leading to a deeper red colour. This means that the brighter, more vibrant red strawberries are likely to contain more anthocyanins and, therefore, higher levels. of these beneficial nutrients.

Roberta Holt, lead researcher of the study at UC Davies, said: "Our review found that regular strawberry consumption not only lowers cholesterol but also helps reduce inflammation, which is a key driver of heart disease. This means that simply adding a cup of strawberries to your daily routine can significantly reduce your risk of cardiovascular events."

Daily consumption of strawberries, in any form, can significantly benefit those at higher risk for heart disease. Strawberries can be eaten raw or incorporated into a meal.

Beyond heart health, researchers also noted the benefits of eating more strawberries for the brain. The study showed that these juicy berries may help delay cognitive decline and protect against dementia and Alzheimer’s due to their flavonoids, keeping the brain sharp as we age.

How do strawberries and polyphenols affect the heart?

Strawberries are a good source of polyphenols, particularly anthocyanins, proanthocyanidins, and ellagitannins. These are all types of antioxidants, granting a number of cardiovascular benefits.

Polyphenols help increase 'good' cholesterol (HDL) and decrease the 'bad' kind (LDL), contributing to a healthier overall cholesterol balance. This 'good' cholesterol is needed in balance to help with crucial bodily functions, according to the British Heart Foundation (BHF), such as the production of hormones and vitamin D, as well as helping with digestion.

Polyphenols also help to reduce inflammation in blood vessels, further protecting our hearts from serious and potentially fatal problems like a heart attack or stroke. Some studies suggest that polyphenols can help regulate blood pressure, according to a research paper on the NIH website.

What about strawberries and brain health?

Plant compounds called flavonoids in strawberries may help to offset inflammation in the brain and delay age-related memory loss, potentially reducing the risk of Alzheimer’s in older adults. Strawberries are one of the most abundant natural sources of pelargonidin.

Some studies suggest that these compounds may help reduce the risk of dementia and Alzheimer's Disease. The bioactive compound has been associated with "fewer neurofibrillary tau tangles" in the brain - one of the major signs of Alzheimer’s disease that accumulate in the brain, according to the Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease.

As promising as the research on strawberries is for warding off health issues like high cholesterol and cognitive decline, it is not a magic solution. Eating more should decrease your risk of such medical conditions, but only if accompanied by a healthy diet and healthy lifestyle choices.

How to add strawberries to your diet:

Strawberries are generally safe to eat for most people, but some people may experience some negative effects, such as potential allergies. If you suffer from a sensitivity to birch pollen or apples, strawberries may also trigger this allergy.

Even for those who are not allergic, overeating strawberries could lead to digestive issues because of their high fibre content. Also, strawberries contain goitrogens, compounds that may interfere with thyroid function, so those with a thyroid condition should also keep their intake to a minimum.

Strawberries are low in calories compared to other fruits, making them an excellent choice for a simple snack or when incorporated as part of a meal. Eating just seven berries counts as one of the easiest ways to stack up on more berries.

Because of their sweetness, most people blend strawberries into smoothies or top other desserts with them, such as yoghurt or ice cream. You could also use them in salads for a refreshing summer twist. Breakfast may also be a good time to get your strawberry fix in. They make great topping choices for pancakes and porridge.
item.author: Surrey Live

item.title: 前配偶联手进行肾脏互换以挽救生命- KOLO | 8新闻 | Ex-spouses team up in kidney swap to save lives - KOLO | 8 News Now
item.description:
RENO, Nev. (KOLO) - In just two weeks, Gary Hauser of Reno will receive a life-saving kidney transplant. The donor making it possible is his ex-wife, Gigi Hauser. But in a surprising twist, she won’t be donating her kidney to him.

Instead, the two are part of a paired kidney exchange. It’s a process that matches two incompatible donor-recipient pairs with each other to “swap” organs, allowing each recipient to get the kidney they need.

The story began when Gary went in for routine bloodwork two years ago.

“I got a call from a frantic doctor,” Gary said. “He couldn’t say much because it was on a voicemail, but I thought he must have mixed my bloodwork up with someone else because I felt fine.”

But the results were accurate: Gary’s kidney function was down to 17%. He was immediately placed on the deceased donor list, where he waited for two years without finding a match. During that time, Gigi stepped forward to be tested as a potential donor. While she was a partial match, the size difference between the two created a major hurdle.

“There are 12 different factors they look at,” Gigi explained. “And I only hit on 6,” Gary added. “The biggest issue is that I’m twice her size. If I took her kidney, I’d be back in 10 years for another transplant.”

That’s when doctors recommended the paired exchange program. Shortly after enrolling, Gary and Gigi were matched with another donor-recipient pair from Tennessee. In late May, Gigi will donate her kidney to a stranger, and in return, Gary will receive a compatible kidney from that stranger’s loved one.

“The cool thing about a paired exchange is that you’re taking two people off the deceased donor list,” said Gigi. “That makes room for everybody else.”

Since Reno hospitals aren’t equipped to handle paired exchanges, the surgery will take place in Salt Lake City. Afterward, Gary will need to stay in Utah for six weeks so doctors can monitor him closely for signs of organ rejection.

“My body, for the rest of my life, will be fighting the kidney,” Gary said.

Despite the risks, Gigi said the decision to donate was never a question.

“You have to be your own motivator,” she said. “Because you lose a lot of battles when you start doubting yourself.”

As for whether the experience has brought them closer, Gary doesn’t hesitate.

“It’s definitely strengthened our bond,” Gary said. “Hell yeah.”

Gary and Gigi have launched a GoFundMe to help cover travel and medical expenses during their recovery.
